data.question: What is the name of the microporous metal-organic framework discussed for high CH4 storage?
What is the topology type of ZJU-25?
What is the chemical formula for the organic linker used in the synthesis of ZJU-25?
At what temperature and pressure did ZJU-25 achieve the DOE target for methane storage?
What method was used to measure the N2 sorption isotherms for ZJU-25?
What is the BET surface area of ZJU-25?
How was the methane storage capacity of ZJU-25 compared to the DOE target?
data.answer: ZJU-25 met the DOE methane storage target of 180 cm3(STP) cm-3 at 300 K and 35 bar.

data.question: What is the role of open metal sites in ZJU-25 for methane storage?
data.answer: Open metal sites in ZJU-25 facilitate strong recognition and adsorption of methane molecules, contributing to its high methane storage capacity.

data.question: Is the methane storage capacity of ZJU-25 saturated at 35 bar?
data.answer: No, the methane storage capacity of ZJU-25 is not saturated at 35 bar and can be further increased under higher pressure.

data.question: What is the initial isosteric heat of CH4 adsorption in ZJU-25?
True or False: ZJU-25 has a lower BET surface area compared to MOF-505 due to its longer linker.
True or False: The volumetric methane storage capacity of ZJU-25 surpasses most examined porous MOFs.
True or False: The primary CH4 adsorption sites in ZJU-25 can take up about 45 cm3 cm-3 at room temperature and 35 bar.
True or False: The pore sizes in ZJU-25 are unfavorable for methane storage.
True or False: ZJU-25's methane storage capacity is attributed solely to its high porosity.
True or False: The synthesis of ZJU-25 involves a solvothermal method.
What is the role of the SQUEEZE process in the structural analysis of ZJU-25?
data.answer: The SQUEEZE process was used to remove the scattering from highly disordered guest molecules in ZJU-25.

data.question: What was the heating rate used in the thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) for ZJU-25?
True or False: The crystallographic data for ZJU-25 was collected at room temperature.
